title: RL30822
content: The Federal Juvenile Delinquency Act allows federal delinquency proceedings for juvenile offenders when state courts are unable to take jurisdiction or for certain serious crimes with federal interest. In some cases, juvenile offenders may be tried as adults. The increase in serious juvenile crime, limited state court jurisdiction, and expanded federal criminal law have led to more federal delinquency proceedings. In early America, children under 7 were considered incapable of criminal responsibility, with a rebuttable presumption of incapacity until age 14. The intellectual capability to entertain criminal intent was assumed to develop over time. Children under seven were considered innocent, with a presumption of incapacity until age 14. However, this presumption could be overturned by evidence of malicious intent, as guilt is based on understanding rather than age. Children as young as eight have been executed for showing consciousness of guilt and malicious intent. In the early 20th century, states established juvenile court systems to separate children accused of crimes from the adult criminal justice system. By 1930, the federal government was the only entity treating child offenders as adults, while states adopted noncriminal approaches to juvenile offenders for rehabilitation. Attorney General Wickersham recommended that juveniles charged with violating federal law be returned to the juvenile authorities of their home state for rehabilitation instead of being prosecuted and convicted. Congress agreed to this approach to address the limitations in federal penal institutions for dealing with juvenile delinquency. The Federal Juvenile Delinquency Act of 1938 addressed limitations in state juvenile court systems by allowing federal proceedings for juveniles charged with capital crimes or misconduct on Indian reservations or military installations. This Act, supplemented by the Federal Youth Corrections Act in 1950, remained essentially unchanged for over thirty-five years. In 1974, Congress substantially revised the Federal Juvenile Delinquency Act to provide basic procedural rights to juveniles under federal jurisdiction and align federal procedures with various model acts and court decisions. Crimes punishable by death or life imprisonment were made subject to federal juvenile treatment for the first time, following Supreme Court decisions on capital punishment procedures. The 1974 revision of federal juvenile law limited the Attorney General's discretion in trying children as adults for serious crimes. Congress further adjusted the law in 1984, repealing the Federal Youth Corrections Act and allowing juveniles to be tried as adults at a younger age.
